annotated_bib.problem_stmt: Information Science is basically about how to manage information and make the information to be used in a better way. What I found not making sense is that most of street parking in Boston are 2-hour limit parking. Even if you find a street parking spot, it’s normally a 2-hour limit parking. It’s not enough for visiting a friend, traveling around the city or having a meal in a popular restaurant. What can you do in the city within 2 hours? All the parking space near Huntington Ave are 2-hour parking, if you have a class right after another class, 2 hours won’t be enough and you don’t have time to move your car. A ticket would appear on your car. The only place that have 4-hour parking is Ruggles Street near West Village, but we are sharing that street with Wentworth. I know that school has parking garages for students and staffs. I started to drive to class occasionally, on the first day of this summer, I thought there should be fewer students on campus so I drove on the first day of class. It took me 10 minutes to park the car that I didn’t need to move it every 2 hours. But if I want to park in the garage for Summer2 Day Parking only, it’s going to cost me $230, which only four days a week that I have to come to school. 2-hour limit in Boston is not a reasonable time for parking. If you stay in the city for couples of years, you would know that it’s hard to park with enough time not only around Boston University in Allston but also Harvard and MIT in Cambridge. report.p: There is a lot going right here. Specifically, I think you do a good job of summarizing the sources. The issue I see is in making claims about relevance. It is often unclear exactly how the source helps you approach the problem, except in a very general way. Where will you get data? What kind of data is important for you? What kinds of models will help you understand and solve the parking problem? Part of this is making a clear case why an Info Science approach is appropriate for this problem; for example, if you simply want all the meters to be 4-hours, then that seems like a problem that a political organizer could undertake--starting a petition or filing paperwork with the city. Why would this problem need an Info Scientist?
